inlineContent.text: KeyboardKit extends Apple’s native APIs and provides you with a lot more functionality. It lets you mimic the native iOS keyboard and tweak its style and behavior, or create completely custom keyboards.

The essential goal for KeyboardKit is to make it easier to create powerful and flexible keyboards. As such, it has a bunch of essential tools and view, and extensions to native types, to make the native APIs more powerful.
KeyboardKit also has a
view that mimics the native iOS keyboard and can be customized & styled to great extent. Much of the views in the SDK are not used directly when you use a system keyboard.
unlocks a lot of essential Pro features. Information about these features can be found at the end of each article.
KeyboardKit has a
namespace with a lot of keyboard-related types, such as
, etc.
Namespaces are used to make the surface API smaller, by nesting types together in logical groups. By typing
followed by a
, Xcode will provide you with a convenient list of types that are included in this essential namespace.
This namespace doesn’t contain protocols, open classes or types of higher importance.
is the most essential type in the library. Just make your
KeyboardController
inherit this class to get access to a bunch of additional capabilities and view lifecycle functions.
KeyboardKit also has a
protocol that aims to make it easier to use KeyboardKit in platforms that don’t support UIKit. This is however not fully implemented yet.
KeyboardKit has an
class that provides observable keyboard state that keeps the keyboard UI up to date with its current state. It has a
reference and lets you get and set
, etc.
You can use this type control the keyboard. For instance, setting the
will update the
accordingly.
KeyboardKit automatically creates an instance of this class and injects it into
, and syncs it with the controller whenever needed.
KeyboardKit has a
protocol that can be used to define the keyboard’s behavior. It’s used by e.g. the
to make behavior-based decisions.
KeyboardKit automatically creates a
and injects it into
. You can replace it at any time.

KeyboardKit extends native types with a lot more information, to make it easier to implement features like autocomplete, text analysis, etc. Check the extension section in the bottom of the documentation root, or the
folder for more info.
KeyboardKit provides essential views that can be used to create keyboards that mimic the native system keyboards for iOS and iPadOS.
KeyboardKit has a
that mimics a native iOS keyboard. It can be used for alphabetic, numeric & symbolic keyboards,
supports all supported locales, layouts, callouts, etc., and can be styled to great extent with styles & themes:
can be customized to great extent. You can pass in custom services & state, and replace any part of the keyboard:

code: controller: controller,             // You can setup the view with a controller instance
buttonContent: { $0.view },         // Can be used to customize the content view of any button
buttonView: { $0.view },            // Can be used to customize the entire view of any button
emojiKeyboard: { $0.view },         // Can be used to customize the emoji keyboard, if any
toolbar: { params in params.view }  // Can be used to customize the toolbar above the keyboard

inlineContent.text: To use the standard views, just return
, or
. Otherwise, just return the view you want to use for the provided params. The view builders provide information to help you setup custom views.
KeyboardKit has a collection of keyboard
views and styles that can be used to mimic all parts of a native keyboard buttons, as well as their gestures. The
renders the full button, while views like
renders parts of it.
Most of the views can be styled with a
, which can be applied with the
view modifier. This is however not yet true for the
itself, which uses a
to support more complex styling.
KeyboardKit has a
that can be used to integrate with the iOS keyboard switcher, to select the next keyboard on tap and shows a keyboard menu on long press.
This button requires a
to trigger controller-based functionality that switches keyboard and shows the menu. KeyboardKit automatically registers the
when it launches.
KeyboardKit will by default map
to this view when rendering the action, which means that you don’t have to do this.
KeyboardKit has a keyboard
that applies a minimum height to its content. It can be used to stop input & action callouts from being cut off, since a custom iOS keyboard can’t render outside of its frame.
This view can be styled with a
, which can be applied with the
view modifier:
See the
article for more information about how styling is handled in KeyboardKit.
unlocks additional, powerful capabilities for the
, such as support for every
, an
, and powerful
and
view.
See the
and
articles for more information.
KeyboardKit Pro adds more views to the SDK, to let you build more complex keyboards with fewer lines of code.
The
can toggle between two toolbars. It’s a great way to place a main menu “behind” the autocomplete toolbar, and let it slide in when tapping the customizable toggle.
This view wraps itself in a
, which means that it can also be styled with the
modifier.

abstract.text: This article describes the essential parts of KeyboardKit.
The default set of keyboard-specific services.
This article describes the KeyboardKit action engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit settings engine.
This protocol is used to abstract the input view controller.
This protocol can be implemented by classes that can define
keyboard-specific behaviors.
This enum defines how much the backspace key deletes.
This namespace contains essential keyboard-related types.
This article describes the KeyboardKit autocomplete engine.
This view mimics a native keyboard button shadow.
This article describes the KeyboardKit external keyboard engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit proxy engine and its utilities.
This enum defines various keyboard return key types, to
make it possible to modify the return key.
This article describes the KeyboardKit gesture engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit text routing engine.
The locale that is currently being used.
The text document proxy that is currently active.

namespace for related types.
This view can be used to toggle between two toolbars.
This article describes the KeyboardKit preview engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit color engine.

will
render for the provided services and configuration.

styles for different parts of a keyboard.
This article describes the KeyboardKit callout engine.

KeyboardKit helps you create custom keyboard extensions with Swift and SwiftUI.
The default set of keyboard-specific state.

This article describes the KeyboardKit keyboard image engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit styling engine.
This class provides keyboard extensions with contextual and
observable information about the keyboard extension.
This view mimics a native keyboard button.
This article describes the KeyboardKit emoji engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit device utilities.
This class is used as global state for a “next keyboard”
operation, since it needs a controller to function.
Represents a keyboard switcher (🌐) button and triggers the keyboard switch action when long pressed and released.
This enum defines various autocapitalization types.
This article describes the KeyboardKit dictation engine.
The keyboard type that is currently used.
This article describes the KeyboardKit layout engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit state engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit feedback engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit AI support capabilities.
This view mimics a native emoji keyboard.
This keyboard can be used to create alphabetic, numeric and
symbolic keyboards that mimic the native iOS keyboard.

with KeyboardKit

height, to ensure that callouts are not cut off.

are implemented by the library.
